articles.headline: The SoftBank Effect: How $100 Billion Left Workers in a Hole
articles.snippet: SoftBank poured money into start-ups that use armies of contractors. That has upended the lives of drivers, hotel operators and real estate agents around the world.
articles.abstract: SoftBank poured money into start-ups that use armies of contractors. That has upended the lives of drivers, hotel operators and real estate agents around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: For five years, Sunil Solankey, a retired captain in the Indian Army, had run the 20-room Four Sight Hotel in a New Delhi suburb. Business was steady, but he longed to make the establishment a destination for lucrative business travelers.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper, Vindu Goel and Arjun Harindranath

articles.headline: Trump Renews Tariff Threat Against China and Touts U.S. Economic ‘Boom’
articles.snippet: President Trump, in an economic address in New York, said his policies have fueled America’s growth but gave little indication that a breakthrough in China trade talks was imminent.
articles.abstract: President Trump, in an economic address in New York, said his policies have fueled America’s growth but gave little indication that a breakthrough in China trade talks was imminent.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Tuesday said the United States was “close” to an interim deal with China and that an agreement “could happen soon,” even as he renewed his threat of additional tariffs.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson, Maggie Haberman and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Intel Fixes a Security Flaw It Said Was Repaired 6 Months Ago
articles.snippet: The chip maker patched several problems in May. Now it is issuing another fix, and researchers say the company hasn’t been straight about its issues.
articles.abstract: The chip maker patched several problems in May. Now it is issuing another fix, and researchers say the company hasn’t been straight about its issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last May, when Intel released a patch for a group of security vulnerabilities researchers had found in the company’s computer processors, Intel implied that all the problems were solved.

articles.headline: Two Impeachments, but Two Radically Different Accusations
articles.snippet: As the House opens public hearings into whether President Trump committed high crimes and misdemeanors, the battle over President Bill Clinton’s impeachment 21 years ago looms large.
articles.abstract: As the House opens public hearings into whether President Trump committed high crimes and misdemeanors, the battle over President Bill Clinton’s impeachment 21 years ago looms large.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The room was charged with electricity the day the House Judiciary Committee opened public hearings into whether to impeach the president of the United States. It felt like the whole world was watching. It felt like the whole world was on edge.

articles.headline: The Man Trump Trusts for News on Ukraine
articles.snippet: Who is John Solomon? His name popped up frequently in closed-door testimony in the impeachment query. He is a regular on Hannity. And his work helps shape how millions of Americans understand this moment.
articles.abstract: Who is John Solomon? His name popped up frequently in closed-door testimony in the impeachment query. He is a regular on Hannity. And his work helps shape how millions of Americans understand this moment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In weeks of closed-door testimony, American officials who worked in Ukraine kept circling back to the work of one journalist, John Solomon, whose articles they said appeared to have considerable currency with President Trump’s inner circle.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: As Push for Higher Minimum Wages Grows, New York Offers a Test Case
articles.snippet: Fed research suggested higher minimum wages did not cost jobs in border counties. Industry-level analysis and real-life stories back that up — with caveats.
articles.abstract: Fed research suggested higher minimum wages did not cost jobs in border counties. Industry-level analysis and real-life stories back that up — with caveats.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIPLEY, N.Y. — Meeder’s, a cozy diner nestled in New York’s southwest corner, has seen its labor bill skyrocket in recent years amid steady increases in the state’s minimum wage.

articles.headline: Subzero Interest Rates Are Luring Insurers to Risk
articles.snippet: Usually the most strait-laced of investors, insurance companies are letting loose to gain some income, drawing the attention of regulators.
articles.abstract: Usually the most strait-laced of investors, insurance companies are letting loose to gain some income, drawing the attention of regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUNICH — It was a crisp fall morning, and Tom Wilson was contemplating the latest sign that the world of finance had turned upside down.

articles.headline: Texting While Walking Is Dangerous. Here’s How to Stop.
articles.snippet: You know you do it. It’s not safe, obviously. Here’s how to take control of your tech use.
articles.abstract: You know you do it. It’s not safe, obviously. Here’s how to take control of your tech use.
articles.lead_paragraph: You’re walking around and a thought occurs: “I should check my phone.” The phone comes out of your pocket. You type a message. Then your eyes remain glued to the screen, even when you walk across the street.
